title: Can the world thrive on 100% renewable energy? - Quora

response.answer_text: This question has a few caveats and answering it properly requires some modifications to the question. First: is it possible? Yes, theoretically, well, most things are possible in the broad sense of the word, but it could still make no sense to do something. It is also possible for me to win Olympic gold medal running (jumping) the Marathon on one leg. But saying that it is theoretically possible gives us no useful information. Many things are possible in this sense. For example, the most straightforward way to do this Full RE100% would be for most of the people to die suddenly, leaving only a handful living somewhere with no access to other energy than what is classified as Renewable. So there would be a “cost” in human lives, and since the question was “regardless of cost” this meets the criteria. Almost the same end result would be achieved if there was some sort of mass-psychosis where people just stopped using everything else but RE. A lot of people would die inside a few months, since their lives are more or less completely dependent on fossil fuels and modern energy and the technologies that use these energy sources. This makes such mass-psychosis unlikely to last for long. But of course, all of this makes no sense in the real world, as these things are not likely to happen even if they are possible. Cost, and not just monetary, but cost in a broader sense, is probably the most important metric for evaluating “how” possible (or probable, or feasible, or desirable) something would be. To answer the original question shortly with some added criteria: Is it practically or politically possible in a reasonable time-frame? No. Too many people (almost all of us) get enormous value and their lives depend on using fossil fuels for the time being. Ramping up alternative energy sources takes time and energy (which is currently 85 % fossil fuels so for a long time we would be doing the transition with fossil fuels powering it). Does RE100% make sense as a goal? Not really. What we want to move towards is a low-carbon, low-environmental-impact, high net-energy and low cost energy supply as fast as possible (meaning, with as little negative disruption to people’s lives as possible, since that is a prerequisite for political feasibility as well). I’m simplifying a lot here to save space (I have written a couple books on the subject in English and Finnish so I could use a lot more space here, believe me :)). This would exclude some renewable energy sources and include nuclear energy in its various forms. Perhaps even some Carbon Capture and Storage (CCS) here and there. The best mix of these would depend on local circumstances. As a final note, I want to include the fact that electricity is only about a fifth of global energy use. Decarbonizing industrial process heat and household/commercial sector heat, transportation fuels and other lesser uses of energy and fuel uses will be a huge undertaking, one that we have not yet even started talking about.

Yes….but not yet. Actually, it is inevitable and is likely to happen within the next 50 years….but not yet. Once we get past the irrational subsidy panic of solar energy production and put it back on a more competitive and sustainable business model, then it may well become a very common design element in nearly every single family home built. Solar technology is already capable of powering single family homes. That will only improve in the future. It also is NOT capable of powering grid level loads and won’t be able to do that until we resolve the technical problem of grid level load storage capacity. It is likely that we will find other renewable energy sources to be more effective, efficient and cost-effective before we resolve that storage problem. These other sources might include hydrogen, fuel cells, MHD, and newer designs for nuclear reactors. Of course, there will be those that argue that nuclear can never be “renewable” but it is more likely that we will reconsider what “renewable” means. If you fill up the fuel tank of an energy production facility once every 40 years, then for all practical purposes, that is a renewable energy source. Such is the nature of the newest nuclear reactor designs. We will eventually outgrow the irrational fear of nuclear energy as the general public (very slowly) learns to ignore the fear mongers and the sensationalist news media in favor of hard core statistics and scientific facts. Fission and breeder reactors in a 5th Gen reactor designs are almost certainly inevitable simply out of the pure economics and practically of their production capability. It comes down to “energy density”. In the future, our demand for electrical power will grow very large and it is unlikely that wind and solar will be a practical solution. Yes, it might be capable but not practical as compared with much more compact and efficient nuclear plants - like molten salt or pebble bed reactors. One nuclear plant can produce 500+ MW peak or over 12,000 MWh per year on about 15 acres of land. By comparison, the largest solar PV farm (in India) covers 247 acres with 120,000 panels and is rated at peak power to produce 20 MW or about 480 MWh per year (when you apply the industry accepted Capacity Utilisation Factors (CUF)). Most of the hype about solar is unfounded, exaggerated or only applies under ideal (laboratory) conditions. Real world experience is much different than the industry and advocate describe…. Is 100% renewable energy possible? It’s the ONLY energy system that is viable long term. Solar, and wind plus a day of pumped hydro and battery storage can provide 99% or so of total grid electrical demand. Waste recycling for hydrocarbon fuels allows existing reserve generators to backup the grid as necessary, provide the long haul air and sea transport fuels and the chemical feedstocks we need. It also eliminates dumping which pollutes including 5% of GHG from humans. This is not incineration or “waste to energy”, this is closed chamber thermal pyrolysis type processing to convert wastes to salable hydrocarbon gases, liquids, charcoal. plus scrap ready metals and glasses. No exhaust, no emissions. Electrically powered so it can make good use of excess solar and wind. Using the charcoal as a soil amendment can double the productivity of poor soils and will sequester the carbon for hundreds of years: waste recycling can be carbon negative. (Biochar) Along the way we will convert near 100% of ground vehicles to electrics and most short haul air and sea transport. For short range air and sea transport, electric versions cost 80% less to operate. The long haul air and sea use the hydrocarbons from recycling our wastes. Everything we can will be electrified. For instance steel is now being made without coke using hydrogen instead, created electrically. There are no technical nor market barriers to going 100% renewable in 10 years if we push. The world is on track, based on historical growth rates, to be 100% renewable in a decade or two. 2030 to 2040, not 2050. Renewable is now cheaper for most people in most places. Meanwhile fossils pollution is killing millions of people per year and driving the climate irreversibly into new and less human friendly climates. Remember renewable has become cheaper without government subsidies or breaks in just the last few years. We need to do this ASAP. Going renewable will save millions of lives and trillions of dollars per year.  Brian Donovan's answer to Can solar power become a major power source in the coming 20 years? If so, why? If not, what are your ideas?

Q: Regardless of cost and interest, is it possible for all countries to use 100% renewable energy? Short answer: No. Questions involving absolute terms like none, all, or 100% simply stunt progress. It’s about balance and a path forward  Sure it’s possible in one context.  So barring the end of what we call civilization and the economy, I must take exception to the 100% premise proposed by the OP. How is one building electrical generation infrastructure or batteries without chemicals and material derived from the petrol chemical industry? Once built, nothing is 100% recyclable. There would need to be new material added to the stream. This question would need to be modified to include some form or allowance for carbon offsets or carbon buy-back. One cannot put windmills and transmission lines in place without cranes and bulldozers and as yet they require fuel. Consider the modern basis of our technology and manufacturing sector. Given modern technology and manufacturing, so much from medicine to agriculture would need to be “reinvented”. We often forget the “oil/energy” sector is really the “petrol-chemical” sector. Every electrical device I have had experience with has been constructed with or made use of materials derived from the petrol-chemical sector. Given the process of extracting many of these chemicals, there are byproducts which are best used or disposed of as energy products. If we have electric cars, where is one getting the asphalt for the roads? Again, many things would need to be innovated and many others reinvented. As yet, the most efficient form of harnessing solar power is photosynthesis. Many talk of bio-plastic alternatives. The late Dr. Albert Bartlett defined modern agriculture as the process of converting fossil fuel into food. If we were to transition to manufacturing products derived and or synthesized from “grown material” then the silviculture industry would have to ramp up to significant levels and much of agriculture, aquaculture effort would need to be diverted. That could have devastating consequences. I live in an area where a wood stove in the neighborhood gives a smell of days gone by. If everyone in the neighborhood had a wood-stove, the particulate alone would be hazardous. While I have seen some of the “old ways” practiced as a hobby; pitch, tar, and coal was still part of their construction. Applied today scrubbers can get the ash and sulfur emissions down. The old ways weren't always so grand. I still occasionally want my BBQ (is charcoal carbon-negative, I believe it is). Questions involving absolute terms like all or 100% simply stunt progress. It’s about balance and a path forward given the current state as a starting point. There are no black and white answers in this world. Progress is one step at a time.

If we don't consider cost or the time to manufacture and install equipment , we can fully transition to 100% renewable energy tomorrow! Ok, enough hyperbole. In reality, it would take a bit longer since production capacity needs to be expanded and this takes time. If the entire world were involved, this could perhaps be carried out in as little as 10 years. Regardless of time, the most important point is that today’s technology doesn't need any fundamental advances to take the world renewable - 100% renewable energy is 100% possible. The biggest challenge we face over the next 30 years, or until 2050 arrives, is how to transition legacy systems to renewables in a manner that (1) doesn't interrupt peoples’ lives and that (2) doesn't break the bank. Incidentally, some argue that breaking the bank is exactly what should be done. Investing in new technology, production methods and advanced systems will give rise to new industries far exceeding the losses made in the decline of the fossil fuel industry. At the core of energy management today, it is not a question of “whether the technology is ready” but rather “which measures should be implemented first”, “who are the key decision makers” and “which transition path will generate the least emissions.” Thanks for reading!

Well, I think it could, but it would require a bit more infrastructure than it has now. Consider; half the Earth is always in sunlight. If you have a grid that wraps all the way around the world, it would always be possible to send energy from the sunlit parts to the dark parts, 24/7. Not that long ago, I read that it’s currently economical to transmit power up to 6000 miles (unfortunately, I no longer seem to have the link to that paper), so with few technical improvements, we could send solar power anywhere on the globe. You wouldn’t even need batteries. Just a grid that would function over borders (probably the biggest hurdle to overcome). Would we “thrive?”. I don’t see how we couldn’t. Nobody would be fighting over oil, at least. If you wanted to limit your distribution to a few thousand miles, then you could always use battery back-up to compensate for weather in certain parts of the country. But batteries are polluters, though there have been major improvements in that area. They also considerably increase the cost of the installation, vs a pure solar full-Earth-grid. You can add nukes, wind, water, geothermal, waves and such to the mix, if you like, but you could do the whole thing just with solar panels.

Absolutely! However, currently there are only four countries in the world that are running solely on renewable energy. Bonaire, Costa Rica and Iceland. Bonaire: The switch from fossil-fueled to renewable energy meant more affordable electricity for this Caribbean island’s 14,500 residents. Bonaire houses 12 wind turbines that generate almost all of its power. The country is also developing a system that would use local algae to create biofuel. Costa Rica: Costa Rica’s president announced that the country had been running on 100 percent renewable energy since the start of 2015 and is working on plans to become carbon neutral within the next six years. They’re investing in hydropower and geothermal power (volcanoes!) and considering wind and solar options as well. Iceland: The island currently generates all of its energy with renewables, which is largely attributed to hydropower – approximately two-thirds. Like Costa Rica, Iceland also taps its volcanic roots for development of geothermal renewable energy. This supplies nearly all of Iceland’s heat and hot water!

If you skip the constraints of economics then it is completely possible. However, we should keep in mind that the production capacity should be very high than the actual demand (load). This is because of the curse attached to renewable: uncertainty and unreliability. For example, in a region close to equator, hourse of operation of PV plants is ~4000 hours/year. This means that we should incorporate some storage units which further costs money (here we don't care about) and efficiency losses. This eventually would force to increase renewable energy capacity further. If we mix various sources of renewable energy, say, wind with PV panels, then also we would require some storage units as they do not perfectly overlay each other. However, it would improve as the daily peaks for solar appear in day time when typically wind suffers production troughs. For getting an idea, if we talk about a standalone microgrid to have 99% renewable penetration we would have to waste ~67% of energy production. This means we need huge capacity as compared to actual demands. This is just an example and actual figures may vary depending on many factors like geographical location, demand-supply etc. Therefore, in order to have a 100% renewable system we need many infrastructural changes which could be much higher generation capacities, ample amount of storage system or super-grid which could have connectivity across the globe to attain a balance of frequency (signifies demand-generation proportion) by handling energy peaks and troughs.

Yes, if you’re willing to conflate “renewable” with “low carbon emissions”. This allows for the use of nuclear power as part of the mix. The snag in a pure renewable economy is that you can have stretches of time in which there’s not much wind and it’s cloudy. Now what? Some uses of electricity require a continuous supply. If you’re smelting aluminum, you need to keep going. A long power interruption can lead to the ruin of expensive equipment. Hospitals need uninterruptible power. Airports. Flood control pumps. And there is more. Now in principle one might build banks of batteries, but batteries are expensive. Their natural use is as short-term storage. The last few percent of “100%” will be extra expensive. You’ll have to make jet fuel from scratch, for example, with chemicals derived from biological processes or reactions driven by electricity. A 90% carbon-free economy would perhaps suffice to stabilize the climate. There are, after all, natural processes which take CO2 out of the atmosphere. The white cliffs of Dover are made of calcium carbonate. So we don’t have to get to absolute zero emissions to get to stability. And at 90%, even ignoring those natural processes, we’ll have ten times as long to come up with technology that bridges the last 10% gap. Now the good news is that nuclear power need not be all that expensive. France has already built and maintained for decades a largely nuclear infrastructure. The other good news is that wind and solar need not be all that expensive. Costs have been plummeting. Some free market deals have been struck (Chile, India, UAE) for solar electricity at wholesale rates of 3 cents per kilowatt hour. Wind, too, is becoming more economical. It is also possible to move electricity from where it is generated to where it will be used with much less transmission loss than now is usual. Use direct current high voltage lines. So we can harvest the wind and the sun in the plains and deserts, and transmit the resulting electricity to cities several hundred miles, or 1000 miles, away. It’s doable. And the larger the scale of our networks, the less the problem of interruptions in supply. The desert is reliably sunny most of the year. The high plains are reliably windy. And if all else fails, most users can be put on short rations for a while and priority users can carry on, their electricity drawn from nuclear power plants.

Depends on what you classify renewable energy as, and if you’re talking about total energy or just electricity. It’s important to note that renewable energy has been classified in a variety of ways that either include or remove sources of energy. For example, according to US Renewable Portfolio Standards, hydroelectric is not considered renewable, but according to the Solutions-Project by Mark Jacobson hydroelectric is renewable. This is important to recognize, because there are some countries that do not have preferable access to forms of solar, or do not have enough resources to physically produce enough units for wind or solar production in their particular countries. Now if you’re including the possibility that all countries would trade resources regardless of economics to provide these technologies to other countries, then you would resolve part of \ this issue. The second and greater question is whether or not you mean total energy or electrical energy generation. This distinction determines if you are talking about solely covering electricity consumption for a country, or if you are talking about all industries that use energy. If you are talking about the latter, and thus total energy then 100% renewable is impossible. This is because there are fundamental industries that require products, which renewables can never produce. For example slag from coal is an aggregate used in cement production. This use of coal is counted in total energy, but not in electricity generation. There is no renewable technology that can replace slag. There are many substitutes for petrochemical commodities, but some materials cannot be replaced with adequate substitutes. There is currently no known substitute that can replace 100% of hydrocarbons in asphalt; therefore, the energy product needed to produce this material is not going to be a “renewable energy product”.

Yes, but it is not easy. 99% is easier and 90% is a lot easier. A “last mile problem” essentially. The lion share of the difficulties up to 99% can be overcome with batteries and other storage technology. The cost of storage is coming down and will reach the inflection point in the next few years. As progress on renewables is behind in most locations there is no gap to talk about. The final 1% is not an issue for about 50 years because there will still be Nuclear power stations which have yet to be decommissioned at that point. Whether we build more Nuclear to carry the 1% going forward or whether another solution arises is hard to say at this point (my preference would be tidal, but it is a tough argument at this point). Note: I notice that your comment is very narrow and excludes many options. Excluding hydro in particular, makes this problem very hard and perhaps impossible in some locations. BTW the best renewable energy is energy which is not wasted. Addressing wasteful energy usage pulls percentages up much faster than alternative spending.

Lets take a more encompassing look at the term ‘renewable’. Synthetic fuels can be made from CO2 and hydrogen ‘harvested’ from sea water. With this in mind, there is enough uranium and thorium to provide power to Earth’s population for 10,000 years. We have been ‘civilized’ less time than that. Somewhere along that time line, controlled fusion might come of age and replace all energy sources (so sez the Sci-Fi books). New fission technology (molten salt reactor) allows enough dense energy to be spread safely around the world to convert sea water’s CO2 and hydrogen into many synthetic fuels (including aircraft fuel). The CO2 produced from the synfuel goes back into solution in sea water. So in larger terms this is as ‘renewable’ as much as timber is - without added CO2. Synthetic fuels will provide a buffer between replacing fossil fuel while conversion to electrical energy progresses. It ain’t cheap. Anyone have a better suggestion?

Reverend Lovejoy: Oh, short answer, "yes" with an "if." Long answer, "no" with a "but." If you mean 100% renewable electricity, that is pretty simple in most places. It will cost more than utility electricity, but if you can afford the price, the technology exists. If you mean 100% renewable lifestyle; food, water, building materials, energy, transport, etc, then you may have difficulty. I think a person might be able to go 100% renewable lifestyle but at huge expense. You can achieve Carbon neutrality - Wikipedia by either changing your lifestyle or by paying for offsets.

I see a lot of answers, from people even more expert than myself. My two cents is that sure, is possible. But it MAY require a substantial rework of our society, and lifestyle. If you accept a model where 99.9+% of the time power is available,m and paid on consumption, maybe. But the requirement to have it the same way (long term, so at least 1 week of storage capacity) will put a huge penalty on price. So how much more are you willing to pay? And there is only that much hydro one can do (Dutch can do none) and at some point the NIMBY syndrome will strike again and that damn do it somewhere else or that wind turbine poisons my morning view…

It is possible to have a 100% renewable life, because we do not exist in a closed system - the sun provides continuous energy to the Earth. Basically what everyone did up until the Bronze Age. The problem with trying to have a 100% sustainable modern life is entropy - things get disordered. Recycled paper has shorter fibres, so that after about 3 generations it falls apart. Landfills accumulate composites like paper/plastic/metal tetrapaks that are difficult to recycle. The natural ecosystem is able to recycle urine and dung and bones as it's powered by the sun (hence not subject to the second law of thermodynamics). Theoretically, we could do the same with technological waste given an external energy source (the sun), but it's much cheaper to just keep mining.

The major unanswered problem facing the use of renewable energy as a significant source of electrical energy (forget about 100%) is the variability in its availability over longer periods of time - months and years. There has been no strategy even offered (much less implemented) that would accommodate a 50% seasonal variation in energy availability, or a strategy that would adapt to a year to year variation in total energy output. Storage of massive amounts of energy ( a large fraction of total yearly US electrical and transportation energy used) is impossible to imagine. Overbuilding capacity by 2 to 3 X to cover for any anticipated negative excursions in energy availability would be very expensive. The silence about this problem is another example of Sherlock Holmes’ barking dog. The lack of any barking by renewable energy advocates is also a message.

At our current rate, we have about 50 years of oil, 100 years of natural gas, and 200 years of coal. If your asking about renewable power output. Solar, by itself, can meet the current energy demands of the world, by using about 0.3% of the land mass. Which is roughly the size of Spain.  Not including wind, geothermal, tide, hydro, or nuclear.

No. Not if you want to fly airplanes or helicopters. Wind energy requires a reliable, switchable backup, usually natural gas. Fossil fuels made our modern prosperity possible. Replacing them with renewables at anything like the pace some people envision would be dangerous if it were even possible.

It is possible from the technical standpoint, using energy storage to offset the variable output of solar panels and wind turbines. However, the price of energy storage is still too high, and the approach is only viable in countries where electricity from the power grid is very expensive. Many things need to happen for the world to use 100% renewable energy: Combined renewable generation + energy storage has to become cheaper than coal-based generation. Hydroelectricity can help, since it can provide energy on demand just like fossil fuel power plants, but site conditions limit hydroelectricity.Electric vehicles have to become more affordable than gas cars.Airplanes still rely on fossil fuels. Mankind will have to develop an aircraft that can use renewable energy somehow.

The Sun has been powering everything for several billion years, and it still is. Wind and Solar PV are able to capture as much of that energy as we can use. But we need to reframe how we think about electricity. This is a work in progress but there are two quotes that summarize the situation, “You never change thing by fighting the existing reality. To change something build a new model that will make the existing model obsolete” B. Fuller and Einstein’s observation “We can’t solve problems by using the same kind of thinking that created them.” There is a new model that will make the existing model obsolete and our biggest challenge is getting people to realize that it will actually create far more profitable renewable energy futures.

Is 100% renewable energy possible? Update, 2019: We are going to stop burning fossil fuels as we convert to less expensive renewable energy, battery-backed grid storage, and electric vehicles. We can have more than 16 terawatts of clean, reliable wind and solar electricity generation capacity, enough for the whole world today, and more as we need more for EVs and Carbon Capture (No, not the absurdity of Clean Coal).

And the energy return on energy invested for biofuel is so low that it would require abandoning a technical lifestyle, including things like electric lights and heated homes.
